image:image.image:title: Design learning for decision quality not completion rates
image:image.image:caption: Learning design often traps us in a completion game. We track how many courses learners finish instead of how well they apply what they learned.

image:image.image:title: Design without losing human judgment
image:image.image:caption: AI tools keep appearing faster than anyone can integrate them into learning design.

image:image.image:title: Design gamification for decision quality, not points
image:image.image:caption: Gamification works when mechanics reinforce better decisions and measurable capability growth, not when they only reward participation.

image:image.image:title: AI feedback works only when it supports human coaching
image:image.image:caption: AI feedback creates value when it amplifies human coaching and improves real decisions, not when it just increases message volume.

image:image.image:title: Game-based learning should change behavior, not just engagement
image:image.image:caption: Game-based learning is useful only when it changes decisions and behavior in real work, not when it just raises participation.

image:image.image:title: The Object Without Attachment
image:image.image:caption: Humans are wired to bond with things we work through, not just finish. When AI compresses effort, you get the result without the emotional imprint that normally makes it feel yours.

image:image.image:title: Where We Go From Here
image:image.image:caption: Every single piece of work I do now starts with an IDE or an AI chat interface, and I haven't touched PowerPoint, Word, or Adobe XD in over five months.

image:image.image:caption: If everyone is losing jobs, who pays for AI infrastructure? It is funded by concentrated capital and by customers, and the risk is who gets left out.
